verses.text: The two angels came to Sodom in the evening, and Lot was sitting at the gate of Sodom. When Lot saw them, he rose to meet them and bowed himself with his face to the ground.
verses.comment: Lot's gesture of bowing shows deep reverence, typical for figures who encounter messengers of God. The city gate was a place of authority and judgment.

verses.text: And he said, 'My lords, please turn aside to your servant's house and spend the night. Wash your feet, then you may rise early and go on your way.' But they said, 'No, we will spend the night in the square.'
verses.comment: Lot offers hospitality, echoing Abraham's earlier encounter. The act of washing feet reflects service and humility.

verses.text: But he pressed them strongly, so they turned aside to him and went into his house. He prepared a feast and baked unleavened bread, and they ate.
verses.comment: Unleavened bread points ahead to the Passover, where haste and purity are symbolized (Exodus 12:8).

verses.text: But before they lay down, the men of the city, the men of Sodom, both young and old, all the people to the last man, surrounded the house.
verses.comment: The widespread corruption of Sodom is emphasized—everyone participated.

verses.text: And they called to Lot, 'Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us, that we may know them.'
verses.comment: 'Know them' is a euphemism for sexual abuse, revealing their depravity. Similar language in Judges 19 suggests a repeated pattern of sin.

verses.text: Lot went out to the men at the entrance, shut the door behind him,
verses.comment: Lot tries to shield his guests, risking himself for their safety.

verses.text: and said, 'I beg you, my brothers, do not act so wickedly.'
verses.comment: Lot appeals to their conscience, showing that some sense of morality remains amidst the city's wickedness.

verses.text: Look, I have two daughters who have not known any man. Let me bring them out to you, and do to them as you please; only do nothing to these men, for they have come under the protection of my roof.'
verses.comment: Lot's offer, although horrific, shows the ancient view of hospitality as an urgent duty—protecting guests, even at great personal cost. This underscores moral dilemmas and the fallen state of humanity.

verses.text: But they said, 'Stand back!' And they said, 'This fellow came to live here, and now he acts as a judge! Now we will treat you worse than them.' So they pressed hard against the man Lot, and drew near to break the door down.
verses.comment: Lot's status as a newcomer is resented by the Sodomites, showing the city's rejection of justice and outsiders.

verses.text: But the men reached out their hands and pulled Lot back into the house with them and shut the door.
verses.comment: God’s agents directly intervene to save Lot, demonstrating both divine protection and the seriousness of the situation.

verses.text: And they struck the men at the entrance of the house, both small and great, with blindness, so that they wearied themselves trying to find the door.
verses.comment: This supernatural blindness underscores God's judgment and the futility of resisting divine will.

verses.text: Then the men said to Lot, 'Whom else do you have here? Sons-in-law, your sons, your daughters, and anyone you have in the city—bring them out of the place.'
verses.comment: A call for urgency to save Lot's family anticipates future rescue motifs in Scripture, including the Passover and deliverance from judgment (Exodus 12:13).

verses.text: For we are about to destroy this place, because the outcry against its people has grown great before the LORD, and the LORD has sent us to destroy it.'
verses.comment: The repetition of 'outcry' recalls Genesis 4:10 and shows how evil calls forth justice from God (James 5:4).

verses.text: So Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who were to marry his daughters, and said, 'Up! Get out of this place, for the LORD is about to destroy the city.' But he seemed to his sons-in-law to be jesting.
verses.comment: Lot’s warning is dismissed, paralleling later themes of people disbelieving prophetic judgment (Matthew 24:38).

verses.text: As morning dawned, the angels urged Lot, saying, 'Up! Take your wife and your two daughters, who are here, or you will be swept away in the punishment of the city.'
verses.comment: The urgency to depart is reminiscent of Noah's deliverance from the flood, and later the Israelites' exodus.

verses.text: But he lingered. So the men seized him and his wife and his two daughters by the hand, the LORD being merciful to him, and they brought him out and set him outside the city.
verses.comment: Lot is saved by sheer mercy, not merit—a theological foreshadowing of salvation by grace.

verses.text: And as they brought them out, one said, 'Escape for your life! Do not look back or stop anywhere in the plain. Escape to the hills, lest you be swept away.'
verses.comment: Obeying God's command without hesitation is often critical. The warning not to look back will have symbolic resonance.

verses.text: And Lot said to them, 'Oh, no, my lords.
verses.comment: Lot's hesitation and negotiations reveal his lack of faith compared to Abraham.

verses.text: Behold, your servant has found favor in your sight, and you have shown me great kindness in saving my life. But I cannot escape to the hills, lest the disaster overtake me and I die.
verses.comment: Lot appeals to mercy but remains reluctant, showing human frailty in response to divine command.

verses.text: Look, that city is near enough to flee to, and it is small. Let me escape there—is it not a little one?—and my life will be saved.'
verses.comment: Lot's plea to go to Zoar (meaning 'small') highlights God's willingness to show mercy in response to humble prayer. This foreshadows prayers of petition later fulfilled in Scripture.

verses.text: He said to him, 'Behold, I grant you this favor also, that I will not overthrow the city of which you have spoken.
verses.comment: Persistent intercession can alter outcomes—a theme found in Moses’ prayers and the role of mediators in salvation history.

verses.text: Escape there quickly, for I can do nothing until you arrive there.' Therefore the name of the city was called Zoar.
verses.comment: Mercy delays judgment—an echo of God’s patience and willingness to grant reprieve in response to intercessory prayer.

verses.text: The sun had risen over the earth when Lot came to Zoar.
verses.comment: Daybreak marks both salvation and judgment—a motif found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Then the LORD rained on Sodom and Gomorrah sulfur and fire from the LORD out of heaven.
verses.comment: The destruction echoes themes of judgment and purification (cf. Malachi 4:1). Sulfur and fire symbolize complete purification, later developed in both literal and spiritual senses.

verses.text: He overthrew those cities, and all the valley, and all the inhabitants of the cities, and what grew on the ground.
verses.comment: Total destruction recalls the comprehensive effects of sin and the necessity for total renewal.

verses.text: But Lot’s wife, behind him, looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.
verses.comment: Lot’s wife’s disobedience serves as a warning for lingering attachment to the world—Luke 17:32 uses this typologically regarding discipleship and forsaking old lives.

verses.text: And Abraham went early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the LORD.
verses.comment: Abraham returns to his place of intercession, emphasizing the importance of standing before God in prayer for others' salvation.

verses.text: And he looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and toward all the land of the valley, and he saw, and behold, the smoke of the land went up like the smoke of a furnace.
verses.comment: The imagery of smoke rising from judgment recurs in later prophecies, symbolizing eternal consequences of rebellion.

verses.text: So it was that, when God destroyed the cities of the valley, God remembered Abraham and sent Lot out of the midst of the overthrow, when he overthrew the cities in which Lot lived.
verses.comment: Lot is saved because of Abraham’s intercession—a theme of mediation reappearing throughout Scripture, prefiguring the role of righteous intercessors.

verses.text: Now Lot went up out of Zoar and lived in the hills with his two daughters, for he was afraid to stay in Zoar. So he lived in a cave with his two daughters.
verses.comment: Fear drives Lot to isolation—echoing times when fear leads to retreat instead of faith, as seen in Elijah’s story (1 Kings 19:9).

verses.text: And the firstborn said to the younger, 'Our father is old, and there is not a man in the earth to come in to us after the manner of all the earth.'
verses.comment: The daughters’ statement reflects both desperation and misunderstanding, as the region’s destruction seemed universal to them.

verses.text: Come, let us make our father drink wine, and we will lie with him, that we may preserve offspring from our father.'
verses.comment: Intentions are to preserve family line, echoing Noah’s drunkenness and the complexities of fallen human conduct.

verses.text: So they made their father drink wine that night. And the firstborn went in and lay with her father. He did not know when she lay down or when she arose.
verses.comment: Such acts later became explicitly prohibited (Leviticus 18:6) and illustrate the chaotic legacy emerging from sin—which requires healing and reconciliation found in later Scripture.

verses.text: On the next day, the firstborn said to the younger, 'Look, I lay with my father last night. Let us make him drink wine tonight also. Then you go in and lie with him, that we may preserve offspring from our father.'
verses.comment: The recurring theme of human effort attempting to solve problems without reliance on God serves as a cautionary lesson.

verses.text: So they made their father drink wine that night also, and the younger rose and lay with him. And he did not know when she lay down or when she arose.
verses.comment: Lot’s ignorance recalls the pattern of Noah's drunkenness and human weakness.

verses.text: Thus both the daughters of Lot became pregnant by their father.
verses.comment: The birth of nations through this incident reveals that God can bring good even from flawed circumstances, foreshadowing redemption from fallen humanity.

verses.text: The firstborn bore a son and called his name Moab. He is the ancestor of the Moabites to this day.
verses.comment: Moab's lineage later intersects with Israel’s story—for example, Ruth—a sign of God’s providential inclusion despite origins.

verses.text: The younger also bore a son and called his name Ben-ammi. He is the ancestor of the Ammonites to this day.
verses.comment: These nations, though born from brokenness, played important roles in salvation history. The redemptive arc from fallen beginnings points to the fullness of reconciliation found in the promises fulfilled through Christ.
